questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition shown in the given X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Giant cell tumor There are four characteristic radiographic features when a giant cell tumor is located in a long bone: Occurs only with a closed growth plate Abuts articular surface: 84–99% come within 1 cm of the articular surface Well-defined with non sclerotic margin (though <5% may show some sclerosis) Eccentric: If large, it may be difficult to assess Features: Location—epiphysis/skeletally mature patient/multiple septa in the lytic lesion (soap bubble appearance). Other epiphyseal tumor is chondroblastoma (which shows punctate calcification)

Highyeild:

B. Benign aggressive tumour Giant Cell Tumor (Osteoclastoma) It is epiphyseal lesion seen most commonly around the knee joint (lower femur > upper tibia). Most commonly seen between 20 to 40 years age C. Clinically egg shell cracking sensation is seen in late stage of tumor, sometimes it can present as pulsatile tumor. Rate of malignant transformation is less than 5 to 10%. Histopathological feature: tumor contains two type of cells. The tumor cell is mononuclear stromal cell. Another kind of cell seen is multinuclear giant cells (not true tumor cells). Treatment: curretage is treatment of choice. Treatment For benign lesions - Simple curettage with bone grafting (autograft/allograft/ artificial bone graft/bone cement) Management of GCT at various locatio ns i. Around knee: A hemicondylarosteo articular allograft reconstruction or a rotating hingeendoprosthesis may be needed. ii. For distal radius: primary resection with a proximal fibular autograft (arthroplasty / arthrodesis) is done iii. Lesion at expandable bones like (distal ulna / clavicle or proximal fibula), primary resection is done iv. For in operable lesion like in pelvis / spine radiation or emobilization or both is done. Important point i. There is risk of sarcomatous changes in lesion treated with irradiation so reserved only for operable lesion. ii. Chemotherapy has limited success.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B: ANEURYSMAL BONE CYST: These are locally destructive, blood filled reactive lesion of bone and are also not considered to be true tumors Most common location is proximal humerus, distal femur, proximal tibia and spine, (posterior elements of vertebra) OPTION C: OSTEOSARCOMA It is characterized by production of osteoid by malignant cells. This is the 2nd most common primary malignant tumor of bone and most common hematologic malignancy of bone. This is the most common radiation associated with sarcoma. This involves metaphysis (less commonly the diaphysis/epiphysis are involved) OPTION D: NOT THE CORRECT OPTION

Table:

#MANTRA Benign aggressive tumour Giant Cell Tumor (Osteoclastoma) It is epiphyseal lesion seen most commonly around the knee joint (lower femur > upper tibia). Most commonly seen between 20 to 40 years age C. Clinically egg shell cracking sensation is seen in late stage of tumor, sometimes it can present as pulsatile tumor. Rate of malignant transformation is less than 5 to 10%. Histopathological feature: tumor contains two type of cells. The tumor cell is mononuclear stromal cell. Another kind of cell seen is multinuclear giant cells (not true tumor cells). Treatment: curretage is treatment of choice. Treatment For benign lesions - Simple curettage with bone grafting (autograft/allograft/ artificial bone graft/bone cement) Management of GCT at various locations Around knee: A hemicondylarosteo articular allograft reconstruction or a rotating hingeendoprosthesis may be needed. For distal radius: primary resection with a proximal fibular autograft (arthroplasty / arthrodesis) is done. iii. Lesion at expandable bones like (distal ulna / clavicle or proximal fibula), primary resection is done For in operable lesion like in pelvis / spine radiation or emobilization or both is done. Important point There is risk of sarcomatous changes in lesion treated with irradiation so reserved only for operable lesion. Chemotherapy has limited success. Features Giant cell tumour Simple bone cyst Aneurysmal bone cyst Fibrous dysplasia Age 20-40 yrs. < 20 yrs. 10-40 yrs. 20-30 yrs Common bones Lower femur, Age Common bones Upper tibia Lower radius Upper humerus Upper femur Tibia Humerus Neck of the femur Tibia Location Epiphysis Metaphysis Metaphysis Metaphysis X-ray Soap-bubble appearance, eccentrically placed Maximum width less than width of the growth plate Distending lesion, 'ballooning' the bone Metaphysis Multi-loculated Ground-glass appearance Trabeculations++ Treatment preferred Excision Curettage and bone graft Curettage and bone graft Curettage and bone graft

questions.text: First reflex to recover after spinal shock is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bulbocavernosus reflex The bulbocavernosus reflex is an oligosynaptic reflex mediated through the S2–S4 spinal cord segments that is elicited by electrical stimulation of the dorsal penis/clitoris nerves with the reflex response recorded from any pelvic floor muscles. The afferent paths of the bulbocavernosus reflex are the sensory fibers of the pudendal nerves and the reflex center in the S2–S4 spinal segment. The efferent paths are the motor fibers of the pudendal nerves and anal sphincter muscles.

Highyeild:

The bulbocavernosus reflex (BCR) is clinically elicited by squeezing the glans penis and digitally palpating the contraction of the bulbocavernosus (BC) muscle. The test involves monitoring internal and external sphincter contraction in response to squeezing the glans penis or clitoris, or tugging on an indwelling Foley catheter. This reflex can also be tested electrophysiologically by stimulating the penis or vulva and recording from the anal sphincter.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A: The Achilles reflex or ankle jerk reflex, mediated by S1 through the sciatic (tibial) nerve and elicited by tapping the tendon of the gastrocnemius muscle OPTION B: The plantar reflex is a nociceptive segmental spinal reflex that serves the purpose of protecting the sole of the foot. The clinical significance lies in the fact that the abnormal response reliably indicates metabolic or structural abnormality in the corticospinal system upstream from the segmental reflex. OPTION C: Cremasteric reflex: This reflex is elicited by stroking the ipsilateral thigh which leads to reflex elevation of the ipsilateral testicle by greater than 0.5cm.

Table:

#MANTRA # BULBOCAVERNOSUS REFLEX Cord transection: In this type, the cord and its surrounding tissues are transected. The injury is anatomical and irreparable. Initially, the motor paralysis is flaccid because the cord below the level of injury is in a state of 'spinal shock'. After some time, however, the cord recovers from shock and acts as an independent structure, without any control from the higher centres. In this state, though the cord manifests reflex activity at spinal level, there is no voluntary control over body parts below the level of injury. There is total loss of sensation and autonomic functions below the level of injury. The appearance of signs suggestive of reflex cord activity i.e., bulbo-cavernosus reflex, anal reflex and plantar reflex, without recovery of motor power or sensations is an indicator of cord transection. These reflexes usually appear within 24 hours of the injury. In a few days or weeks, the flaccid paralysis (due to spinal shock) becomes spastic, with exaggerated tendon reflexes and clonus. Involuntary flexor spasms at different joints and spasticity leads to contractures. Sensation and autonomic functions never return.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during flexion

options.label: B
options.text: Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension

options.label: C
options.text: Inferior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during flexion

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension

questions.correct_answer: B. Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior pole of patella and impinging on femoral component during extension Patellar Clunk syndrome is a painful condition associated with mechanical catching or clunking during active extension following total knee arthroplasty (TKA). The syndrome is caused by growth of interposing soft tissue usually at the superior pole of the patella. This interposed soft tissue cannot be visualized on plain radiographs. It is seen following total knee arthroplasty. It is a painful condition and is caused by growth of soft tissue most commonly at the superior pole of the patella.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A,C AND D ARE NOT THE CORRECT OPTIONS

questions.text: The Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is which of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Pain on passive stretching of toes

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain on passive stretching of toes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pain on passive stretching of toes The earliest symptom of acute compartment syndrome is pain. Pain out of proportion to clinical situation is usually the first symptom in compartment syndrome of leg while pain on passive stretching is most sensitive sign prior to the onset of ischemia. This is the most frequent in the lower leg.

Highyeild:

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME: AREA- DEEP POSTERIOR COMPARTMENT OF THE LEG SYMPTOM- PAIN OUT OF PROPORTION TO INJURY SIGN-PAIN ON PASSIVE STRETCH AT DISTAL-MOST JOINT OF EXTREMITY NORMAL PRESSURE- <11 mmHg, Calf pressure during walking:200-300 mmHg Treatment: Fasciotomy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A,B AND C ARE NOT THE CORRECT OPTIONS

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A 9 year old came to OPD with the following deformity of his left upper limb,most likely fracture causing it is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supracondylar fracture The given image is that of cubitus varus also known as gun stock deformity, which is a common complication of supracondylar humeral fracture.

Highyeild:

Malunion is a common complication in supracondylar fractures. However, backward or sideways shifts are gradually smoothed out by modelling during growth, and they rarely give rise to visible deformity of the elbow.Forward or backward angulation may limit flexion or extension, but consequent disability is minimal. Uncorrected sideways angulation and rotation are much more important and lead to varus (or rarely valgus) deformity of the elbow. This is permanent and will not improve with growth . (Figure in the question). Since the fracture extraphyseal, physeal damage cannot be blamed for the deformity but usually, a faulty reduction is responsible. Cubitus varus is disfiguring, and cubitus valgus may cause late ulnar nerve palsy.If the deformity is marked, it will need correction by supracondylar osteotomy,once the child approaches skeletal maturity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B: Olecranon Fractures are common fractures of the elbow that lead to loss of extensor mechanism. Diagnosis can be made with plain radiographs of the elbow. Treatment may be nonoperative for nondisplaced fractures with an intact extensor mechanism. Surgical management is indicated for displaced fractures or fractures associated with loss of extensor mechanism. OPTION C: Radial Head Fractures are common intra-articular elbow fractures that can be associated with an episode of elbow instability, a mechanical block to elbow motion, an injury to the distal radioulnar joint and/or to the interosseous membrane (Essex-Lopresti). OPTION D: NOT THE CORRECT ANSWER

questions.text: A 20 year old man came to the ortho OPD with the following deformity. The most appropriate management at this stage is:

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.correct_answer: A. Splint the finger in flexion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splint the finger in flexion Mallet finger: A finger deformity caused by disruption of the terminal extensor tendon distal to DIP joint. The disruption may be bony or tendinous. It is a common injury usually due to forced flexion of the distal phalanx while the extensor tendons are actively trying to extend the finger. It is also known as Baseball finger, Drop finger, and Cricket finger. The tip of the affected finger remains flexed when the hand is extended, resembling a mallet. First line of treatment: Splinting

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION B: Buddy strapping is done by strapping your injured finger to the finger next to it; this protects your injured finger or hand while allowing you to move it to prevent stiffness OPTION C AND D ARE NOT THE CORRECT OPTIONS.

Table:

#Mantra Some common splints used in Orthopaedics Splint Used for Cramer wire splint Immobilization of fractures in emergency Cock up splint Radial nerve injury Knuckle bender splint Claw hand Thomas splint Fracture shaft of femur Taylor's Brace Dorsolumbar immobilization SOMI brace (Sternooccipitalmandibular immobilization) Cervical spine immobilization ASHE Brace (Anterior spinal hyperextension brace) Dorso lumbar spine immobilization Aeroplane splint Brachial plexus injury Milwaukee brace Scoliosis Risser's cast Scoliosis Toe raising splint Foot drop SOMI - Sternal occipital mandibular immobilize ASHE anterior spinal hyperextension brace

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and wound with discharging pus from right thigh for 4 months. Given below is the X-ray with labeled structure. Identify:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sequestrum Sequestrum is the hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis. Sequestrum: It is a dead bone surrounded by granulation tissue. It appears dense (white similar to normal bone) because there is no demineralization.

Highyeild:

Chronic Osteomyelitis Chronic osteomyelitis is very difficult to eradicate. After medical management the symptoms may subside, but the foci of infection may persist and flare up with decrease in immunity. Hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis are sequestrum/involucrum and cloacae. The causes for chronic osteomyelitis can be: tuberculosis, fungal or many other organisms. Clinical sign & symptoms Tenderness is almost always present. Chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presentation. C. Thickened irregular bone is associated. Stiff adjacent joint may also be associated with chronic osteomyelitis. Investigation Blood investigations: ESR/CRP are raised; WBC may also be raised X-Rays may show Sequestrum It is an infected dead bone surrounded by granulation tissue. It appears dense on x-ray as normal calcium metabolism does not take place because of avascularity Involucrum is reactive new formation around the infected cavity. Cloacae are apertures in involucrum Thickening and irregularity of cortices are also seen E. CT scan help in localizing sequestrumMRI shows margin of bone and soft tissue edema. Gold standard test is aspiration biopsy with culture and sensitivity. Treatmentinfusion Sequestrectomy A window is made in the bone and infected dead bone is removed. It is done when proper involucrum is formed or it may cause pathological fracture with saucerization for free drainage of the infected material. Can be supplemented with continuous suction and drainage Antibiotics (as per culture and sensitivity) Excision of the bone Amputation in rare cases can be done Complication of chronic osteomyelitis Acute exacerbation is the most common complication. ABG B. Growth abnormalities in children usually a deformity or shortening can be there.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION B: Cloacae: They are apertures in involucrum. They are created due to pressure of the granulation tissue over the involucrum. That is the new bone formation. OPTION C: Involucrum: It is a reactive new bone formation. OPTION D: NOT THE CORRECT ANSWER

Table:

#Mantra DIFFERENT TYPES OF SEQUESTRA Type Disease Tubular Pyogenic Ring External fixator Black Actinomycosis Coralliform Perthe's disease Coke Tuberculosis Sandy Tuberculosis Feathery Syphillis

questions.text: A patient presented with pain in his ankle. X-ray was done which shows osteolytic lesion with sclerotic rim. HPE findings are attached. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemophilic pseudotumor X-ray is useful in diagnosing intraosseous pseudotumors. They appear as well-defined, unilocular or multiloculated, lytic, expansile lesions of variable size. In this case, it can involve metaphysis, diaphysis, and epiphysis of long bones. Other findings include endosteal scalloping, perilesional sclerosis, cortical thinning or thickening, trabeculations, and septations. Pathological fractures can also be present. Haemophilic pseudotumours are rare complications of haemophilia consisting of a progressive cystic swelling of muscle and/or bone due to repeated bleeding, occurring in <2% of haemophiliacs.

Highyeild:

Hemophilia Hemophilia is an X linked recessive disorder characterized by the deficiency of factor VIII (hemophilia A or classical hemophilia) or factor IX (hemophilia B or christmas disease) Clinical manifestation Swelling of knee which is due to bleeding in joints weight bearing joints are most commonly involved, with the frequency of involvement in decreasing order, knee>elbow> shoulder> ankle> wrist> hip. Intramuscular bleeding In lower limbs most common sites of bleeding is Iliopsoas followed by quadriceps. In upper limb the most common site of bleeding is deltoid. The hematoma can increase in size and may cause pressure necrosis and erosion of bone so also known as pseudotumor. Nerve Palsy may occur due to compression by hematoma. Treatment Replacement of factors Ice and analgesics Brace support and compression bandages

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - OPTION A: Eumycetoma occurs after a traumatic inoculation of filamentous fungi in barefoot walkers in endemic areas. OPTION B: Ochronosis is the bluish-black discoloration of certain tissues, such as the ear cartilage and the ocular tissue, seen with alkaptonuria, OPTION D: Pigmented villonodular synovitis (PVNS) refers to a subtype of tenosynovial giant cell tumors that diffusely affect the soft tissue lining of joints and tendons
